summary: The text describes a biblical narrative where Elisha curses a group of mocking children in the name of the Lord, resulting in two bears attacking them. This event is allegorically linked to the condemnation of the Jewish people after they insulted the Savior during his crucifixion. The narrative also alludes to historical events, drawing a parallel with the Jewish defeat by the Roman leaders Vespasian and Titus forty-two years after the crucifixion. The text further discusses the symbolism of a lion's roar, referencing the antichrist as a figure of great deception and fear, using secular power to oppress. This lion imagery is also linked to a biblical psalm where the antichrist's treachery is likened to a lion waiting in ambush.
